questions.text: A patient is undergoing craniotomy for a subdural hematoma. During the procedure, the surgeon requests lowering the intracranial pressure to facilitate brain relaxation and surgical exposure. All the following can be used, except
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Ketamine is the only intravenous anaesthetic that increases Cerebral blood flow(CBF) by dilating cerebral vasculature and raising cerebral metabolic rate (CMRO2). Ketamine may also impede the absorption of CSFwithout affecting formation.
  • Ketamine increases cerebral blood flow, cerebral blood volume, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) volume, which can significantly raise intracranial pressure (ICP), especially in patients with reduced intracranial compliance. Therefore, it is contraindicated in conditions where maintaining a low ICP is critical.
  • Effect of ketamine on other systems:
    • Cardiovascular
    • ↑ Heart rate & BP (sympathomimetic action)
    • Useful in shock/hypotension
    • Avoid in ischemic heart disease
  • Respiratory
    • Bronchodilator (good in asthma)
    • Minimal respiratory depression
    • May increase secretions (→ laryngospasm risk)
  • Gastrointestinal
    • ↑ Salivary and bronchial secretion
    • Mild nausea/vomiting
  • Endocrine/Metabolic
    • It increases the intracranial pressure (ICP) and intraocular pressure (IOP)and also causes an elevation in the levels of Cortisol and glucose (transient).

Explanation of other options:

Mannitol(Option A): In doses of 0.25 to 1 g/kg, is particularly effective in rapidly decreasing intracranial fluid volume and ICP.

Furosemide(Option B): Increases intravascular oncotic pressure via hypo-osmolar diuresis, which reduces cerebral oedema and CSF production.

Hyperventilation(Option C): Intermittent positive pressure ventilation is given with aim of achieving low normal arterial CO2 (PaCO2 35 mm Hg) by hyperventilating which will help to reduce cerebral swelling and hence intracranial pressure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman diagnosed with pheochromocytoma is scheduled for adrenalectomy. Which preoperative preparation is most appropriate to prevent intraoperative hypertensive crises?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

  • α-blockade (phenoxybenzamine or selective α2-blockers) initiated 1–2 weeks preoperatively ensures normalisation of blood pressure and expansion of intravascular volume. A beta blocker is added only after adequate α-blockade is achieved for tachycardia.

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumour originating most commonly from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla, and it releases epinephrine, norepinephrine, and occasionally dopamine.

  • Classically follows the “rule of 10s”:
    • 10% bilateral
    • 10% extra-adrenal (paraganglioma)
    • 10% malignant
    • 10% familial
  • Classic symptom triad:
    1. Headache
    2. Palpitations (tachycardia)
    3. Diaphoresis
  • Treatment - Surgical management with careful pre-op preparation

Explanation of other options:

  • Beta-blockade with propranolol alone(Option A): Giving a beta-blocker first is dangerous.It blocks β2-mediated vasodilation, leaving unopposed α-adrenergic vasoconstriction, potentially worsening hypertension .Only used after alpha-blockade, if tachyarrhythmia persists.
  • High-sodium diet with liberal fluids only on the morning of surgery(Option C): High-sodium intake and fluid resuscitation are part of pre-op prep after initiating alpha-blockade, not a stand-alone or same-day measure. Given to correct volume contraction from chronic catecholamine excess.
  • Administration of magnesium sulfate only(Option D): Magnesium sulfate has vasodilatory and anti-arrhythmic properties, and may be used intraoperatively or during hypertensive crisis, but not as a replacement for alpha-blockade.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic abruptly stops alcohol consumption. After a period of abstinence, he develops confusion, agitation, hallucinations, and tremors. At what time after cessation of alcohol is delirium tremens (DTs) most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Early mild symptoms of alcohol withdrawal can be seen within 6 to 8 hours after a substantial drop in the serum alcohol levels. DTs, which is seen in about 5% of patients, is a life-threatening medical emergency that develops 2 to 4 days after the cessation of alcohol in alcoholics.
  • Symptoms of DTs include hallucinations, combativeness, hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension or hypotension, and grand mal seizures.
  • Treatment of severe alcohol withdrawal consists of:
    • Fluid replacement, electrolyte replacement, and IV vitamin administration with particular attention paid to thiamine.
    • Aggressive administration of benzodiazepines is indicated to prevent seizures (5-10 mg of diazepam every 5 minutes until the patient becomes sedated but not unconscious).
    • β-Blockers are used to suppress overactivity of the sympathetic nervous system, and lidocaine may be effective in the treatment of cardiac dysarhythmias. 

Drug therapy for alcohol withdrawal and intoxication

questions.text: A 78-year-old patient with multiple myeloma is admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for treatment of hypercalcemia. He presents with muscle weakness ,lethargy, polyuria and dehydration. ECG showed QT interval shortening. What will be the primary risk associated with anaesthetizing patients with hypercalcemia (levels of 14-16 mg/dL)
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Hypercalcemia(>14mg/dl) is a medical emergency and is associated with a number of signs and symptoms, including hypertension, dysrhythmias, shortening of the QT interval, kidney stones, seizure, nausea and vomiting, weakness, depression, personality changes, psychosis, and even coma.
  • Cardiac effects include:
    • Shortened QT interval
    • Bradyarrhythmias, heart block, and ventricular arrhythmias
  • Higher calcium levels may be associated with clinical symptoms and should be treated before anaesthetizing the patient, along with rehydration and ECG monitoring. Caution should be taken with digitalis administration to any patient who is hypercalcemic because some patients may exhibit extreme digitalis sensitivity.

Explanation of other options:

  • Coagulopathy(Option A): Hypercalcemia is not typically associated with coagulopathy. Coagulation abnormalities are more common in hypocalcemia or liver dysfunction.
  • Hypotension(Option C): While dehydration from polyuria can lead to intravascular volume depletion, which might cause hypotension, it is not the most direct or life-threatening risk.
  • Laryngospasm(Option D): It is typically seen with airway stimulation or inadequate depth of anaesthesia, and not directly caused by hypercalcemia

questions.text: Below what value of cerebral blood flow (CBF) will signs of cerebral ischemia first become evident on the electroencephalogram (EEG)?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • The human brain is able to maintain neuronal function in the face of decreasing CBF below the normal level of 50 mL/100 g/min. Because O2 delivery is directly related to CBF, EEG evidence of cerebral ischemia will appear if CBF is diminished sufficiently.
  • The CBF reserve, however, is substantial, and the first signs of cerebral ischemia do not appear on EEG until CBF has fallen to approximately 22 mL/100 g/min.

questions.text: In which of the following neurological disease conditions is Scopolamine contraindicated as a premedication?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Scopolamine is a centrally acting anticholinergic that crosses the blood-brain barrier.The principal feature of Alzheimer's disease is progressive dementia.
  • One biochemical feature of this disease is a decrease in the enzyme choline acetyltransferase in the brain. There is a strong correlation between reduced enzyme activity and decreased cognitive function.
  • So, scopolamine can worsen the cholinergic deficit and cause confusion and delirium.

questions.text: The MOST sensitive early sign of malignant hyperthermia (MH) during general anaesthesia is
questions.solution:
Explanation

  • The earliest and most sensitive sign of MH is a sudden, unexplained increase in end-expiratory CO2 despite constant minute ventilation. This reflects accelerated CO2 production due to hypermetabolism in skeletal muscles.
  • Malignant Hyperthermia (MH) is a pharmacogenetic disorder triggered by volatile anaesthetics or succinylcholine, most commonly due to mutations in the ryanodine receptor 1 (RyR1) gene and in 25% of cases, the mutation is in the CACNA1S gene coding for L-type voltage-gated calcium channel.
  • These mutations cause excessive calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, leading to:
    • Sustained muscle contraction and rigidity
    • Myonecrosis
    • Hypermetabolism
    • Severe hyperthermia
  • Resulting in:
    • Muscle rigidity, especially masseter spasm (after succinylcholine)
    • Tachycardia and tachypnea
    • Hyperthermia (often a late sign, not always present early)
    • Acidosis (both metabolic and respiratory)
    • Hyperkalemia, leading to arrhythmias
    • Myoglobinuria → cola-colored urine, risk of renal failure

choices.text: Unrecognised obstructive pulmonary disease and high baseline Paco2

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman is anaesthetised for a right hemicolectomy lasting 3 hours. At the end of the operation, the patient's blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg, heart rate is 84 beats/min, core body temperature is 35.4°C, and Peco2 on the infrared spectrometer is 38 mm Hg. Which of the following would be the LEAST plausible reason for prolonged apnea in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Persistent intraoperative hyperventilation (especially to PaCO2 < 20 mm Hg for >2 hours) can lead to CSF alkalosis due to active transport of bicarbonate out of the CNS.
  • However, this condition does not cause prolonged apnea post-op, because once ventilation is normalised, CO2 levels quickly rise and breathing resumes.

Explanation of other options:

  • Residual neuromuscular blockade(Option A): Common cause of postoperative apnea, especially in elderly patients .Even partial paralysis may prevent adequate ventilation.
  • Opioid-induced respiratory depression(option B): Elderly patients are more sensitive to opioids due to reduced clearance and increased brain sensitivity.Can cause apnea with preserved hemodynamics.
  • COPD with baseline hypercapnia(Option C):A plausible cause if the patient has undiagnosed chronic CO2 retention; they may have a reduced ventilatory drive. Postoperative CO2 narcosis can cause apnea.

choices.text: Obtain a measurement of peak flow

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with severe rheumatoid arthritis undergoes pulmonary function evaluation before an elective abdominal surgery. Forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and FVC are within normal limits; however, the maximum voluntary ventilation (MVV) is only 40% of predicted. The next step in the pulmonary function evaluation of this patient should be to
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Maximum voluntary ventilation (MVV) is a nonspecific pulmonary function test that measures the endurance of the ventilatory muscles and indirectly reflects the compliance of the lung and thorax as well as airway resistance.
  • A decreased MVV may be caused by impairment to inspiration or expiration. In this patient, FEV1 is normal, which strongly suggests that the ventilatory impairment is during inspiration. A flow-volume loop would be a very useful confirmatory test.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with chronic kidney disease is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. Which of the following neuromuscular blocking agents is most appropriate for use in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

  • Atracurium is metabolised by Hoffman’s elimination (a temperature and pH-dependent process), making it independent of renal or hepatic function.
  • Pancuronium, Rocuronium and Vecuronium are dependent partially on renal clearance.

Explanation of other options:

  • Pancuronium(Option A): Primarily excreted by the kidneys (about 80%).
  • In CKD patients, accumulation of the drug can occur, leading to prolonged neuromuscular blockade.
  • Rocuronium(Option B): Metabolised by the liver, but about 30–40% is excreted renally.In CKD, clearance is reduced, and duration of action is prolonged.
  • Vecuronium(Option D): Primarily hepatic metabolism, but around 20–30% is excreted by the kidneys. Its active metabolites (3-desacetyl vecuronium) are also renally excreted and can accumulate in CKD, causing delayed recovery.

questions.text: A 68-year-old, 100-kg patient is undergoing a transurethral resection of the prostate gland under general anaesthesia. Upon arrival in the recovery room, the patient appears restless and confused. Serum sodium is checked and found to be 110 mEq/L. How many mEq of sodium are needed to raise the serum [Na+] to 120 mEq/L?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

  • Acute decreases in serum sodium, due to absorption of bladder irrigating fluids, rarely cause symptoms unless the sodium level drops below 120 mEq/L.
  • At this level, tissue edema may develop and clinical neurologic signs (e.g., restlessness, nausea, confusion, seizures, and coma) or ECG changes (e.g., widening of the QRS complex, elevation of the ST segment, ventricular tachycardia, or ventricular fibrillation) may be manifested.
  • Treatment of mild decreases in serum sodium (i.e., 120-135 mEq/L with no neurologic or ECG changes) is by fluid restriction and/or administration of a diuretic such as furosemide.
  • When the sodium level drops below 120 mEq/L and neurologic symptoms or changes in the ECG develop, sodium chloride administration is needed.
  • Formula Sodium required = TBW × Desired change in Na+
    • TBW (Total Body Water) = 0.6 × body weight in kg(e.g., for 100 kg patient: TBW = 60 L)
  • In this Case:
    • Desired rise in sodium = 120 – 110 = 10 mEq/L
    • Sodium required = 60 L × 10 mEq/L = 600 mEq
  • Caution is advised in administering sodium because too rapid administration may lead to central pontine myelinolysis. The recommended rate of 3% sodium chloride (513 mEq/L) is 1 to 2 mL/kg/hr. Serum sodium levels should be checked at least every hour until the sodium level increases above 120 mEq/L.

questions.text: In what percentage of patients does the development of trismus following intravenous administration of succinylcholine indicate the onset of malignant hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Trismus (masseter spasm) is characterised by rigidity of the jaw muscles while the limb muscles remain flaccid after administration of succinylcholine. Trismus may herald the onset of MH in some patients, but may be due to a number of other causes and may occur in normal patients. It had previously been believed that 50% of patients who experience trismus after administration of succinylcholine would go on to develop MH.
  • Recent evidence suggests, however, that the incidence is less. If masseter spasm occurs in a patient after administration of succinylcholine, the most conservative course would be to cancel the operation. If cancellation of the operation is not feasible, then a nontriggering anaesthetic should be used, and the anesthesiologist should pay close attention for any signs of MH.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is scheduled for elective laparotomy. Which of the following is the most appropriate anaesthetic approach to minimise perioperative respiratory complications?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

  • Regional anesthesia is preferred over general anesthesia in patients with moderate-to-severe COPD whenever feasible, particularly for lower abdominal or peripheral surgeries.
  • It will avoid the need for airway intubation and mechanical ventilation, reduce risk of infection and bronchospasm, decrease post-operative pulmonary complications like atelectasis and pneumonia

Explanation of other options:

  • General anaesthesia + N2O(Option A)There is a Risk of bullae rupture, postoperative pulmonary issues
  • High spinal anaesthesia (Option B) There Risk of intercostal muscle paralysis → ↓ ventilation
  • Ketamine (Option D) There is a need for mechanical ventilation and intubation, which is risky in COPD patients.

questions.text: Malignant Hyperthermia and neuroleptic malignant syndrome share each of the following characteristics EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • In Malignant Hyperthermia, vecuronium (a non-depolarising neuromuscular blocker) does not relieve rigidity, since the problem is at the skeletal muscle level (calcium release from sarcoplasmic reticulum).
  • In Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome, rigidity may respond to neuromuscular blockade, since the problem is central dopaminergic dysregulation.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man with myasthenia gravis arrives in the emergency room confused and agitated after a 2-day history of weakness and increased difficulty breathing.
ABGs on room air are:
• Pao2 60 mm Hg
• Paco2 51 mm Hg
• HCO3 - 25 mEq/L
• pH 7.3
• Sao2 of 90%
His respiratory rate is 30 breaths/min and tidal volume (Vt) is 4 mL/kg. After administration of edrophonium 2 mg IV, his Vt declines to 2 mL/kg.He is diaphoretic, has miosis, profuse salivation, bradycardia, and abdominal cramping. What should be the most appropriate step in the management of this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

  • This patient is in acute respiratory failure as the ABG analysis clearly indicates:
    • Hypercapnia (PaCO2 > 45 mmHg) → hypoventilation
    • Hypoxemia (PaO2 < 60 mmHg)
    • Low pH (acidemia)
  • High respiratory rate (30/min) = compensatory mechanism
  • VT is critically low (< 4 mL/kg), and declines further after edrophonium.
  • Edrophonium test interpretation:
  • Edrophonium = short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor
    • If weakness improves → Myasthenic Crisis
    • If weakness worsens → Cholinergic Crisis
  • With a cholinergic crisis, there are significant muscarinic effects (e.g., salivation, bradycardia, miosis) and an accentuated muscle weakness. Because this patient's Vt decreased with the administration of edrophonium, the diagnosis of cholinergic crisis is made. Although atropine may be needed to treat the cholinergic symptoms, muscle weakness will be worse and these patients need to be intubated until the muscle strength returns.

choices.text: Chronic obstructive lung disease treated with a terbutaline inhaler and aminophylline

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus is posted for elective hernia surgery. He is currently on subcutaneous insulin therapy. Which of the following co-existing conditions increases his risk of developing perioperative hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Insulin metabolism involves both the liver and kidneys. Renal dysfunction, however, has a greater impact on insulin metabolism than does hepatic dysfunction.In chronic kidney disease (CKD), insulin metabolism is reduced, so insulin remains longer in the bloodstream giving prolonged effect.
  • Also gluconeogenesis taking place in kidneys will be impaired thus reducing the endogenous glucose production.
  • Other perioperative causes like NPO, decreased oral intake etc will add to this.

Explanation of other options:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis with high-dose prednisone(Option B):Prednisone (a corticosteroid) induces hyperglycemia(not hypoglycemia)by:
    • Increasing insulin resistance
    • Promoting hepatic gluconeogenesis
  • COPD treated with terbutaline and aminophylline(Option C):Beta-agonists (terbutaline) and xanthines (aminophylline) may cause mild hyperglycemia not hypoglycemia through:
    • Glycogenolysis
    • Lipolysis
  • Manic-depressive disorder treated with lithium(Option D):Lithium can interfere with thyroid and renal function,Does not directly impact insulin metabolism

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be associated with a falsely elevated Sao2 as measured by pulse oximetry (dual wave)?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

  • Carboxyhemoglobin absorbs 660 nm light (red), similar to OxyHb → pulse oximeter interprets it as saturated haemoglobin, giving a falsely high reading.
  • Most pulse oximeters illuminate tissue with two wavelengths of light: 660-nm red light and 940-nm infrared light. Because carboxyhemoglobin has an absorbance at 660 nm, very similar to O2 haemoglobin, it produces a falsely elevated Sao2 when present in the blood.
  • Haemoglobin F, bilirubin, and fluorescein dye have no effect on pulse oximetry.(option A&D ruled out)
  • Methylene blue, as well as indigo carmine and indocyanine green, lowers the Sao2 as measured by pulse oximetry(Option C ruled out). Methemoglobin absorbs red and infrared light equally well and gives saturation readings of 85%.

choices.text: Onset of symptoms an hour after end of operation

questions.text: Which of the following findings is NOT consistent with a diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

  • Mixed venous oxygen tension(MVo2) would be very low in malignant hyperthermia due to hypermetabolic status of the cells.
  • Early Clinical Signs:
    • Tachycardia
    • Tachypnea
    • Hypercarbia
    • Paco2: 100–200 mm Hg
    • Muscle rigidity (especially masseter or generalized)
    • Trismus after succinylcholine administration
    • Mixed venous oxygen tension: Very low
